title: Rudy Giuliani splits from his own attorney as he says he will defy subpoena from Democrats' subpoena
text:
Mike Pence and Donald Trump's personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani said on Tuesday they will not cooperate with a U.S. House of Representatives impeachment inquiry into Trump's efforts to pressure Ukraine to investigate a political rival.

The decision to defy congressional subpoenas opens the two men to possible contempt of Congress charges and illustrates Republican Trump's determination to stonewall the Democratic-led impeachment effort, which threatens to consume his presidency.

The refusal to cooperate could be considered as evidence of obstruction of justice, which would substantiate suspicions about Trump's misconduct, according to an official working on the inquiry who communicated on condition of anonymity.

Pence's counsel, Matthew Morgan, said in a letter to the three Democratic lawmakers leading the inquiry that the scope of documents requested included some 'which are clearly not vice-presidential records, pursuant to a self-proclaimed 'impeachment inquiry.''

No: Mike Pence, last seen Monday, said through his counsel that he would not comply with a subpoena from the House Intelligence, Oversight and Foreign Affairs committees

Defiance: Rudy Giuliani said he was not submitting documents demanded by three House committee chairs, including Intel Committee chairman Adam Schiff

Morgan said Pence's office was prepared to work with the committees if they 'wish to return to the regular order of legitimate legislative oversight requests, and the Committees have appropriate requests for information solely in the custody of the Office of the Vice President.'

Morgan, shared the news in a letter to the chairs of the investigating committees.

He claimed the inquiry 'has been designed and implemented in a manner that calls into question' the members' 'commitment to fundamental fairness and due process rights.'

And Giuliani said he would simply wait to see what lawmakers do.

'If they enforce it then we will see what happens,' Giuliani told ABC News of the subpoena.

Giuliani, the president's personal attorney, also said he had split from Jon Sale, who was acting as his attorney for the congressional investigation.

Sale sent a letter to Congress Tuesday - the day the documents lawmakers' subpoenaed were due - to say Giuliani was not complying with the request, he told The Hill newspaper.

Giuliani had hired the former Watergate prosecutor solely to assist him in responding to the subpoena.

Since that work is done, Sale said, he is no longer representing the former New York City mayor.

The subpoena for Giuliani is connected to Trump urging Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigation Joe Biden and his son Hunter Biden's business dealings in the country, as well as Giuliani's role in U.S.-Ukraine relations.

Giuliani has been Trump's main defender since revelations of the call came to light and has conducted multiple media interviews, some of which have left the president's supporters fuming that Giuliani is digging Trump and himself in a deeper hole with his public comments.

The former New York City mayor said last week he would not testify before lawmakers as long as Democratic Rep. Adam Schiff heads the House Intelligence Committee.

'I wouldn't testify in front of that committee until there is a vote of Congress and he is removed,' Giuliani told The Washington Post. 'Let them hold me in contempt. We'll go to court. We'll challenge the contempt.'

He has also threatened a lawsuit against Schiff.

Schiff, meanwhile, is looking into punishments for those who defy Congressional subpoenas, including fining those who refuse to comply.

White Collar attorney Jon Sale (pictured) is no longer representing Rudy Giuliani

'You could fine someone $25,000 a day until they comply. You can do that. We’re looking through the history and studying the law to make sure we’re on solid ground,' he told Axios.

Anyone who doesn't comply with a congressional subpoena can be held in contempt of Congress. The matter usually goes to the courts from there but is often time consuming process.

Schiff told MSNBC the fines could be 'even quicker than the impeachment proceeding or the court proceeding.'

Giuliani's defiance comes as deputy assistant Secretary of State George Kent, whose duties include oversight of relations with the Ukraine, is testifying behind closed doors to lawmakers about attempts by Trump and Giuliani to persuade Ukrainian officials to pursue investigations into the Bidens.

As far back as March, Kent was pointing to Giuliani’s role in what he called a 'disinformation campaign' intended to use a Ukrainian prosecutor to smear targets of the president, including then U.S. Ambassador to the Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch, whom Trump later fired.

Giuliani's defiance comes as Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for European and Eurasian Affairs George Kent testified to lawmakers about Giuliani's role in Ukraine relations

Yovanovitch testified to lawmakers last week.

Additionally U.S. ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland is expected to testify on Thursday that President Trump gave Giuliani the authority to approve a presidential meeting with the president of Ukraine.

Sondland, who was a key figure in communications about handling Ukraine policy, also will testify he met in the Oval Office with Trump, U.S. Ukraine envoy Kurt Volker, and Energy Secretary Rick Perry after he attended Zelensky's inauguration, NBC News reported.

A Trump-Zelensky meeting, which Zelensky in U.S. text exchanges is described as keen to have occur to shore up his own position, would need to get a green light from Giuliani to occur, Sondland will say.

Democrats expect him to provide crucial information about pressure for Ukraine to investigate the Bidens at a time when the Trump administration was holding back $391 million in U.S. security aid to Ukraine.

Additionally, national security official Fiona Hill testified Monday that former National Security Director John Bolton called Giuliani a 'hand grenade who's going to blow everyone up.'

As Trump's personal lawyer, Giuliani has spent months seeking to dig up dirt on Joe Biden's son Hunter's dealings in Ukraine. Hunter Biden took a lucrative post on a board of a Ukrainian energy company, but told ABC News Tuesday he didn't do anything wrong.

Federal prosecutors indicted two Giuliani associates last week on campaign finance violations.

Giuliani told Reuters this week he was paid $500,000 to work for Fraud Guarantee, the company co-founded by Ukraine-born Lev Parnas, who authorities accuse of steering hundreds of thousands of dollars from another source to a pro-Trump super PAC.
description: The president's personal attorney and then the vice president refused to hand over documents to the Democrats' impeachment inquiry, potentially giving evidence they are obstructing justice.
